text: more light has been shed today on the
human cost of the corona virus pandemic
across the United Kingdom the latest
official figures for the first time
include all deaths linked to the virus
including those in care homes and other
community settings and they show that
the pandemic has so far claimed nearly
4,000 more lives than were being
recorded under the previous system now
the latest figure over a 24 hour period
is 765 deaths across the UK it means
that the total number of deaths so far
in the UK of those who tested positive
for coronavirus is now 26 thousand and
97 our health editor Hugh Pym has been
studying these new figures and explains
the implications happier times for betty
celebrating her 97th birthday she's now
in critical care in hospital with
coronavirus her daughter Andrea says she
picked up the virus in a nursing home
and testing at an earlier stage for
residents and staff might have kept her
safe I think it's a bit late I think
that coronavirus if the truth be known
is endemic in our nursing homes and the
people that are going to suffer the most
are the elderly in the vulnerable not to
mention the staff testing for all care
home residents and staff including those
without symptoms has now been made
available either with kits sent to the
homes or mobile units visiting them
managers say they need help running the
testing and it's urgently needed I do
think that there is a tsunami of deaths
that we that we probably we may have
been able to avoid should we have had
this testing an awful lot earlier
because the elderly do not they don't

normally have rip-roaring temperatures
they can be it can be quite insidious
they just a bit off-color I asked about

weeks and
is a huge national and local endeavor to

q PM BBC News well in Scotland more than
half of deaths linked to coronavirus are
now happening in care homes according to
the latest figures from the national
records of Scotland
our correspondent Lorna Gordon is in
Glasgow with the latest details for us
issue these figures show that the number
of people dying from confirmed or
suspected coronavirus in care homes has
overtaken the number of people dying in
hospitals here in
Gotland for the first time since the
outbreak began just over a third of all
covert related deaths in Scotland have
been in care homes but week on weeks of
the number of deaths and care homes has
continued to rise and that means that
the figures show that in the seven days
up to Sunday more than half of all those
who've been dying from confirmed or
suspected coronavirus were care home
residents that equates to one kovat
related death in a care home every 30
minutes while Scotland's First Minister
Nicola Sturgeon said the proportion of
deaths was deeply distressing she said
it was broadly in line with what's being
reported in other countries she also
today outlined the measures that's been
taken to health care homes opposition

skin care homes for ex-service men and

this confirms that if the virus does

with me in the studio is our social

the kind of crisis we're seeing now in

well it's first off important to
remember that we are talking about
Cairns looking after some of the most
vulnerable older and disabled people in
society and across Europe there have
been issues over a high number of deaths
in care homes but in England in
particular this is a system that has
been under pressure underfunded and in
crisis for a long time now it's also
fragmented more than 15,000 care homes
some are privately owned some
not-for-profits a few run by local
authorities more than 400,000 residents
about half pay for their own care about
half are publicly funded so it is
complicated and when I look back at my
reports right at the beginning of all of
this we had
providers saying of PPE our protective
equipment is being diverted to the NHS
we need more testing of staff and
residents and their voices have become
increasingly desperate as the weeks of
going on
unlike the NHS there is no single
powerful voice for social care
no one arguing their case no one shaping
a national response to a national crisis
and whilst the increase in testing
that's coming now is welcome
there are many care providers who say
it's simply too late and in time there
will be some really important questions
we need to ask about what needs to be

Care into a wider health and care system
and properly recognize what they do I
listen many thanks again I was not there
